p.seg: êyakô sâkahikan êh-misâk , nimitaw isi wîkiwak opwâsimôwak , êkotah êh-mihcêticik . To the south of that great lake dwelt some Assiniboine, and they were many.
kîtahtawê pêyak awa nâpêw ocawâsimisah âhkosiyiwa . Then at one time a certain man's child fell sick.

hâtah êh-atoskêmot , êh-nanâtawihimiht , êh-tipahikâkêt otêmah mîna wîkiwâw mîna otayôwinisiwâwa , tahkih mistah âhkosiyiwa . Although he employed medicine-men to have the child doctored, and paid out his horse and his tent and his clothes, yet the child remained very sick.

mîna pâskisikan mêkiw ,
pitanê pimâtisit ntawâsimis ! êh-itêyihtah . he gave also his gun, thinking, “Would that my child might live!”
mâka namoya kîh-miyw-âyâyiwa . But they could not get the child well.
piyisk nipiw aw âwâsis . Finally that child died.

êkosi êkwah kitimâkisiw awa nâpêw mîn âw îskwêw , pisisik êh-mâtocik , ê-mawîhkâtâcik otawâsimisiwâwa , piyisk kinwêsk . And so then that man and woman were poor, and they were always weeping, lamenting their child, for a long time.

kîtahtawê kîksêpâ êh-wâpahtahk ê-wîh-wâpaniyik , sipwêhtêw awa nâpêw ,
nikwatis nika-papâ-ma-mâton , êy-itêyihtah . Then early one morning, when he saw that day was at hand, that man went off, thinking, “Off by myself somewhere I shall go about and weep.”
sipwêhtêw , mostoswayânisah êh-akwanahot , ê-mamêhkocinêt . He went away, wrapping himself in a buffalo hide, without his inner garments.

nama kêkway oskotâkay ; nama kêkway otâsah ; pikoh otâsiyânah , êkwah omaskisinah , êkwah ocâhpîhcisah , êkot ê-asiwatêyik êkotah môhkomân êh-apisâsiniyik . He wore no coat; no leggings; he had only his breechcloth and his moccasins, and his pouch, which contained a small knife.
êkos îsi sipwêhtêw aw ôpwâsimôw , ê-sîkâwit . In this guise the Assiniboine set out, because he was in mourning.
wâhyawês êh-ayât , atih-mâtôw . When he had gone a ways, he wept as he went on.
êkwah êh-pa-pimohtêt , ôma kâ-misâk sâkahikan êkotah sisonêh êh-pimi-ma-mâtot , piyisk wâhyawês ayâw . And, as he walked along, weeping by the shore of that big lake, at last he had gone quite far.
namoya wâpahtam mîkiwâhpah . He could no longer see the tipis.

êkwah pôni-mâtôw , êh-ây-ispatinâyik êkotah êh-itohtêt ,
êkotê ispatinâhk nik-ây-apin , êh-itêyihtah . Then he ceased weeping, and went to where there were some hills, thinking, “There on a hilltop I shall sit.”

pîhtaw êy-astâhikot ayîsiyiniwah , êkwah ê-ntawâpamikot ,
kiyâm wâpamitwâwi ayahciyiniwak , nika-nipahikok , iyikohk kâ-mihtâtak ncawâsimis , êh-itêyihtah . Now that he had come here, he began to be frightened by the thought of Blackfoot, who might come and see him, but he thought, “If the Blackfoot see me, let them kill me, so much do I grieve for my child.”

êyakô ê-wîh-at-âmaciwêt , namoya mistah ê-ispatinâyik , awas-itah kotak mistahi ispatinâyiw , êkotah kâ-wâpamât , ôm itêh k-ôh-ayât ohci , êh-at-âmaciwêyit ayîsiyiniwah , wâpowêyân ê-kikasâkêyit , pâskisikan êh-tahkonamiyit , êh-ati-nîpawiyit mâna , ê-nanâtawâpiyit . As he was on the way, climbing a smaller hill, there rose beyond it another very high one, and there he saw, from the place he had reached, a man climbing up, a man wearing a blanket-robe and holding a gun, who stood still every little ways to reconnoitre.
êkwah wîstah ka-kitâpamêw . Then he, in his turn, kept watching the other.
namoya wâpamik . The other did not see him.
piyisk kêkâc ê-kîs-âmaciwêyit , nahapiyiwa , êh-ati-pimitâcimoyit . At last, when the other had nearly reached the top of his hill, he squatted down and went on, crawling.

êh-kîs-âmaciwêyit , êkotah pimisiniyiwa , kâ-wâpamât itâpâkan êh-ayîtisinamiyit , ê-wîh-kakwê-wâpamâyit awiyah , itêh kâ-wîkicik êkotê isi êy-is-îtâpiyit . When he had reached the summit, there he lay, and he saw him turning a spy-glass this way and that, trying to get sight of someone, as he kept looking out in the direction where the Assiniboine were encamped.
mâka namoya nôkwaniyiwa mîkiwâhpah , awasâyihk êh-wîkiwiht . But the tipis were not visible, for they were camping behind a rise in the land.
piyisk kinwêsk kitâpamêw . At last he had watched him a long time.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpamât êh-tapâhtiskwêyiyit , namoy ê-nanâtawâpiyit . Presently he saw him lower his head and no longer look about.
miyâmay êh-nipât , itêyihtam , êkwah k-êtohtêt . “Doubtless he is sleeping,” he thought, and started to walk in that direction.
itah kâ-kîh-atih-âmaciwêyit , êkotah at-ay-itohtêw . He kept walking along where the other had climbed to the hilltop.
mâskôc ayahciyiniw , âhpôh êtokê opwâsimôw , itêyihtam . “Probably he is a Blackfoot, and yet for all I know, he may be an Assiniboine,” he thought.
itah kâ-kîh-nahapiyit êy-ihtât , kâ-wâpamât êh-tapâhtiskwêsiniyit . When he came to where the other had squatted down, he could see him lying with lowered head.
namoya nisitawêyimêw . He could not tell who he was.
namoya wâpamêw ôhkwâkaniyiw . He could not see his face.

êkwah pêyâhtik pimohtêw ,
mâskôc pêkopayicih , nika-nipahik , ê-ytêyihtahk . He walked carefully, thinking, “If by chance he should wake up, he would kill me.”
piyisk ksiwâk otihtêw . At last he got near to him.
êh-kitâpamêt , kâ-wâpamât êh-kitôwêhkwâmiyit . When he looked at him, he saw that he was sound asleep and snoring.
piyisk otihtêw . At last he came right up to him.
êh-kitâpamât , êkotah pâskisikan astêyiw êkwah itâpâkan . When he looked at him, there lay a gun and a spy-glass.
êkwah êh-pakwahtêhoyit wâpahtam , maskisinah ê-sêkwasoyit . And he saw that he had extra moccasins tied in his belt.

êh-kitâpamât , ocihciyiwah ômis îsi êh-nipâyit ,
êh-aspiskwêsimot ocihciyah , kâ-wâpahtahk êh-kâh-kîskicihcêyit . When he looked at him, as he slept there with his hands like this, “He is resting his head on his hands,” he thought, and then he saw that he had some fingers cut off.
ayahciyiniw êcik âwa ! itêyihtam . He concluded, “And so he is a Blackfoot.”
êh-nanâtawâpit , kâ-wâpamât asiniyah . He looked about him and saw a stone.
asêhtêw , êh-otinât asiniyah . He walked back and took the stone.

êkwah êh-itohtêt itah kâ-nîpawiyit , êh-nahikâpawistawât , ostikwâniyihk êh-pakamahwât asiniyah ohci , nipahêw . Then he went there where the other had stood, and took a good footing close to him, and hit him on the head with the stone, and killed him.

êkosi pâskisikan otinam , mîna itâpâkan , oskotâkayiw , omaskisiniyiwa , otâsiyiwa , mîna kaskitêw , mîna môsw-asiniyah . hen he took the gun, the spy-glass, his coat, his moccasins, his leggings, and the powder and bullets.
êkos kîwêw . Then he went home.

êkâ h-nisitawêyimât ,
mâskôc ahpôh nêhiyaw nipisci-nipahâw , êh-itêyihtahk , êkâ k-ôh-manisamwât wêstakayiwa . Because he did not know who the other was, and thought, “Perhaps I have by mistake slain a Cree,” was why he did not cut off the other's scalp.
êkosi kîwêw . So he went home.
osâm kinwêsk nôcihtâw , ôhi kâ-wîh-kakwê-nipahât . he had been too long killing that man.

êkoyikohk kêkâc êh-âpihtâ-kîsikâyik , takohtêw wîkiwâhk , êkwah êh-âcimot ôma , k-êsi-wâpamât ayîsiyiniwa , asiniyah ohci êh-pakamahwât . When it was almost noon, he reached their camp, and then he told of how he had seen a man and killed him with a stone.

seg.gloss: I killed him while he slept.
These things which I am bringing are his possessions.

p.seg: mâskôc ahpôh nêhiyaw , êh-itêyimak , êkâ k-ôh-manisamwak ostikwân , itwêw . Because I thought of him, 'perhaps he is Cree,' is why I did not take his scalp,” he said.
ê-kiskinôhahk anim ispatinâw , ispayiwak êh-têhtapicik kotakak nâpêwak . When he had pointed out that hill, other men mounted and rode there.
êh-wâpamâcik , nisitawêyimêwak ayahciyiniwa . When they saw him, they recognized him as a Blackfoot.
êwakonik manisamwêwak wêstakâyiwa , êh-kîwêhtatâcik . These men now cut off his scalp and took it home.

êh-takohtêcik , êkoyikohk êkwah miywêyihtamwak opwâsîmôwak , êkwah êh-nîmihitocik , êh-miyawâtahkik ê-nipahâcik ayahciyiniwah . When they arrived, the Assiniboine were glad, and danced, rejoicing because they had killed a Blackfoot.
êkosi êyakô . So much for this.

kîtahtawê ntawih-sipwêhtêwak , êkwah aw âyahciyiniw itah kâ-pimisihk kâ-nipahiht , kîkwa têhtahêwak . Presently they set out for that place, and where that Blackfoot lay who had been slain, they put him up on something. LB on {kîkwa}: Word-avoidance, {têsipicikan}: “scaffold”.

êkwah ôma itah kâ-kê-pimisihk asiskiy êh-manisahkik , tâpiskôc ayîsiyiniw êh-pimisihk êkosi êh-isi-manisahkik ; Then they cut away some of the ground where he had lain, cutting it like a man lying there;

êkwah aw ôpwâsimôw itah k-ôh-wâpamât ôh âyahciyiniwa , êkotah mînah asiskiy êh-ati-manisahkik , tâpiskôc itah êh-pimohtêt ayîsiyiniw êy-isi-manisahkik asiskiy . and there whence that Assiniboine had seen that Blackfoot, there too they went cutting the ground, carving it out like a man walking.

itah mînah êh-ati-nakît mâna , êkotah ê-manisahkik asiskiy , piyisk êh-otihtât ôh ayahciyiniwah . And there where he had stopped on his way, they cut the ground, and finally where he had reached the Blackfoot.
êkwah mîna asiniyah k-ôtinât , êkotah mîna êh-manisahkik asiskiy . And where he had taken the stone, there too they carved out the ground.

itah êh-tahkoskêt , êkwah mîna itah êh-nîpawit , ôh êh-pakamahwât ayahciyiniwa , êkosi êy-isi-kiskinawâcihtâcik . Where he stepped, and also where he stood as he killed the Blackfoot, even so they marked it.

ôh ayahciyiniwah itah kâh-pimisiniyit , itah êh-itiskwêsihk itah kâ-masinahikâsot , êkotah êh-ahâcik ôh âsiniyah . Where the Blackfoot had lain, there where the head of the image lay, there they placed that boulder.

mâmaskâc êkwoyâk êy-isi-wâpahtahkik ôh îyahciyiniwah , êh-nipâyit , ê-mosci-pakamahomiht asiniyah ohci . It wonderfully resembled their actual experience, the sleeping Blackfoot being struck by a stone held in the hand.

êkô ohci k-ôh-masinahwâcik ,
kinwêsk ta-nôkwan , êh-itêyihtahkik . The reason they made the image of him was that they thought, “For a long time let it be visible.”
tâpwê kinwês kêh-nôkwaniyiw êyôkô . And truly, for a long time this thing was to be seen.
êkoyikohk êh-iskwâk âcimowin . This is the end of the story.
